summary: The two patterns by which agents connect sandboxes (8 minute read) Sandboxes provide a workspace where agents can run code, install packages, and access files. summary: In defense of not reading the code (13 minute read) Not reading the code is a bet on the trajectory. The tools may not be perfect, but they're good enough for many use cases, and they're improving incredibly quickly. The bet is that models will continue to improve. People shouldn't be reckless, but code will soon become an implementation detail, and directly interacting with it will not be how engineers make sure it is correct.

summary: How ChatGPT cites social media (3 minute read) Social media continues to play a growing role in AI sourcing. Instagram favors content, as reels and posts make up 65% of citations versus 30% for profiles.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-02-13, Reading time: 1 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fposts%2Ftaimoortariqx_most-companies-overcomplicate-lead-scoring-share-7427332356769935363-w52c%3Futm_source=tldrmarketing/1/0100019c56e4cb17-35f890e2-c4fd-4bda-a3db-9f154cccd740-000000/X4kL0bN_XCytlSyv0eAuK6FQEFt8Jfnepj5fpRvfG6g=444
summary: Lead scoring tip (1 minute read) Brands overcomplicate lead scoring by combining revenue potential and likelihood to close into one number. The better approach is to keep them separate. Use revenue potential to tier leads based on size or deal value, and use conversion likelihood driven by firmographic fit and engagement signals to score them. Focus on the few factors that actually correlate with closed deals.

summary: Useful Guidelines and Calculators for UX Research (11 minute read) UX research should challenge assumptions and reduce risk rather than validate pre-made decisions. Start with small sample sizes (5 interviews per segment) to identify critical issues before scaling up. Effective research requires clear goals first, then appropriate questions, methods, and sample sizes, while triangulating both quantitative behavioral data and qualitative motivational insights.

summary: Building Embedding Models for Large-Scale Real-World Applications (44 minute presentation) Building embedding models consists of multiple steps, from contrastive learning, distillation, evaluation, to serving via document indexing and approximate nearest-neighbor search in vector DBs with optimization on query latency (batching, quantization). title: Introducing Logical-First Architecture, the Real ‚ÄúZero-Copy‚Äù Architecture
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-02-16, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.datamanagementblog.com%2Fintroducing-logical-first-architecture-the-real-zero-copy-architecture%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019c66230c28-21b592cd-cb6d-4261-b1d5-896629d9960a-000000/IjeXc4BTeQHG4hxfXh5finkyaRIwmitvdrEDlD4P5jQ=444
summary: Introducing Logical-First Architecture, the Real ‚ÄúZero-Copy‚Äù Architecture (4 minute read) A Logical-First Architecture is a true zero-copy approach that prioritizes logical access over physical data movement, leaving data in its original sources while enabling unified views, federation, and querying without duplication. Unlike traditional ETL/ELT pipelines or lakehouses that replicate data, it avoids storage bloat, latency, governance complexity, and unnecessary cost.

title: Bias Toward Action
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-02-16, Reading time: 17 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Faddyosmani.com%2Fblog%2Fbias-towards-action%2F%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019c66335a94-028c14eb-82c0-4dab-82c4-270158ceb4fd-000000/tsSngAp3SD5GPOHN6iwUzLDwcWmE53WifDyM15k3hqY=444
summary: Bias Toward Action (17 minute read) Bias toward action is defaulting to the smallest responsible step that produces real feedback while pre-committing to guardrails. It helps companies learn faster while making sure that being wrong doesn't kill them. It's about optimizing for learning speed while investing in foundations that make you faster. Fast teams use a lot of information, but they don't wait for perfect information. Their tight feedback loops allow them to learn quickly.

summary: How NOT to Answer the Salary Question (12 minute read) Job seekers should avoid answering the salary question too early in the interview process. Candidates should deflect the question by focusing on industry-standard ranges, the comprehensive benefits package, or the detailed nature of the role itself.

summary: Hard problems in social media archiving (14 minute read) Institutions face challenges in archiving social media, which differ greatly from individual efforts. Some difficulties include the overwhelming scale of content, the struggle to preserve private or ephemeral media, and capturing the dynamic user experience and opaque algorithms.
